model.checker_program:
{-# LANGUAGE DeriveGeneric #-}
-- {{{
module Main where

import Control.Applicative
import Control.Monad
import Control.Monad.State
import Data.List
import Data.Maybe
import Data.Function
import Data.Tuple
import Data.Ix
import Data.Monoid
import System.Environment
import Text.Read hiding (lift)

import qualified Data.Map.Strict as M
import qualified Data.Set as S

import Control.Arrow
import Data.Char
import qualified Data.ByteString.Lazy as B
import Text.Printf                           -- printf "%0.6f" (1.0)
import Data.Aeson
import GHC.Generics
-- }}}

data Request = Reqest {
      expected_outputs:: [String]
  } deriving (Show, Generic)

instance FromJSON Request

type Coord = (Int,Int)
type Box = M.Map String [Coord]
type Move = (String,(Coord,Coord))

data Problem = Problem
    { rowN, colN  :: Int
    , target      :: String
    , initBox     :: Box
    , isSolution  :: Box -> Bool
    }

nonDetMove :: [Coord -> Coord]
nonDetMove = [ first  (+ 1)
             , first  (subtract 1)
             , second (+ 1)
             , second (subtract 1)
             ]

grow :: Problem -> Box -> String -> S.Set Coord
grow p box name = grow' S.empty S.empty ((:[]) .fromJust . M.lookup name $ box)
    where
      otherCells = mconcat (map S.fromList (M.elems (M.delete name box)))
      grow' _ valids [] = valids
      grow' visited valids  (x:xs)
          | topLeft x `S.member` visited = grow' visited valids xs
          | all (`S.notMember` otherCells) x &&
            all (inRange ((0,0),(rowN p-1,colN p-1))) x =
                let moves = [ map f x | f <- nonDetMove ]
                in grow' (S.insert (topLeft x) visited)
                         (S.insert (topLeft x) valids)
                         (xs ++ moves)
          | otherwise = grow' (S.insert (topLeft x) visited) valids xs

validate :: String -> String -> String -> IO Int
validate input output expOutput =
  return $
  if validateOutput input output expOutput
  then 1
  else 0

validateOutput :: String -> String -> String -> Bool
validateOutput inputStr outputStr expOutputStr = isJust validate
    where
      problem = parseInput inputStr
      optimal :: Int
      optimal = read . head . lines $ expOutputStr
      outputs = lines outputStr
      readMove :: String -> Maybe Move
      readMove s = do
          let line = words s
          guard $ length line == 3
          let (a:c1:c2:_) = line
          (x1,y1) <- readMaybe c1
          (x2,y2) <- readMaybe c2
          return (a,((x1,y1),(x2,y2)))

      performMove :: Box -> Move -> Maybe Box
      performMove b (n,((x1,y1),(x2,y2)))= do
          cells <- M.lookup n b
          guard $ topLeft cells == (x1,y1)
          guard $ (x2,y2) `S.member` grow problem b n
          let dx = x2 - x1
              dy = y2 - y1
              newCells = map ((+ dx) *** (+ dy)) cells
          return (M.insert n newCells b)
      validate :: Maybe ()
      validate = do
          n <- listToMaybe outputs >>= readMaybe
          guard $ n == optimal
          guard $ length outputs == n+1
          let parsedMoves = mapMaybe readMove (tail outputs)
          guard $ length parsedMoves == n
          finalBox <- foldM performMove (initBox problem) parsedMoves
          guard $ isSolution problem finalBox

parseInput :: String -> Problem
parseInput = evalState parseInput' . lines
    where
      parseInput' :: State [String] Problem
      parseInput' = do
          let nextLine :: State [String] String
              nextLine = gets head <* modify tail
              readPair xs = let (a:b:_) = words xs in (read a, read b)
          (m,n) <- readPair <$> nextLine
          rawPuzzle <- map words <$> replicateM m nextLine
          tgt <- nextLine
          tgtCoord <- readPair <$> nextLine
          let box = M.fromListWith (++)
                  . filter (not . all (== '.') . fst)
                  . map (second (:[]) . swap)
                  . tagWithCoord $ rawPuzzle
              isSol = (== tgtCoord) . topLeft . fromJust . M.lookup tgt
          return (Problem m n tgt box isSol)
      tagWithCoord = concat
                 . zipWith (\row ->
                            map (\(col,x) ->
                                 ((row,col),x))) [0..]
                 . map (zip [0..])

topLeft :: [Coord] -> Coord
topLeft = (,) <$> fst . minimumBy (compare `on` fst)
              <*> snd . minimumBy (compare `on` snd)


main :: IO ()
main =
  liftM (takeWhile (not. isSpace). dropWhile isSpace) getContents >>=
  \runDir -> (B.readFile. (runDir ++) $"request.json") >>=
  return. (\(Right x) -> expected_outputs x). (eitherDecode :: B.ByteString -> Either String Request ) >>=
  \files -> forM (zip [(0::Int)..] files)  (tmpFunc runDir) >>=
  \status -> print (getScore status) >>
  (putStrLn. unwords. map show $status)
  where
    getScore testStatus = (fromIntegral. sum$ testStatus) / genericLength testStatus
    tmpFunc runDir (idx, expOutput) = do
      input <- readFile. (runDir++). printf "input%05d.in" $ idx
      output <- readFile. (runDir++). printf "output%05d.out" $ idx
      validate input output expOutput
model.body_html:
The time limit for this challenge is 4 times the standard time limit.

Klotski is a classical puzzle. In this puzzle, you are given a rectangle box of a fixed size with some blocks inside of it. One of these blocks is special, we will call it the "target" block. To solve this puzzle, you will need to slide blocks within this box to move the target block to a specified place.

To slide a block, you must follow certain rules:

  • Blocks can only be moved in four directions: up, down, left and right.
  • Overlapping blocks are not allowed.
  • Blocks can never be moved outside of the box.

Your task is to find one optimal solution for the Klotski puzzle. A solution consists of a sequence of moves that takes the puzzle from its initial state, to a solved state.
For a solution to be considered optimal, there should not be another sequence of moves whose length is less than the current solution.

Note that the definition of "one move" might be different from what you might expect. In the puzzle, you might choose one block and move it anywhere, as long as the above rules are followed. As long as you don't change the block you are currently moving, the whole sequence of movements counts as only one move, regardless of how far that block has moved. Examples will be given in following sections.

Input format
Two integers, and , are given in the first line, where is the number of rows and is the number of columns.
In the following lines, each line contains strings separated by spaces.
Each character in the string describes one cell of the Klotski puzzle.
A string consists only of '.'s (e.g. ".", "..."), which stands for empty cells, while other strings encode blocks.
The next line contains one string, which indicates the target block.
The last line contains a coordinate that specifies the place where the target block should be moved to. This coordinate is the top-left corner where the target block should be placed.

For example, you might be given a puzzle like this:

3 4
A A C .
A B C .
B B . .
B
0 1

This Klotski puzzle consists of 3 blocks:

# Block "A", top-left corner is (0,0)

A A . .
A . . .
. . . .

# Block "B", top-left corner is (1,0)

. . . .
. B . .
B B . .

# Block "C", top-left corner is (0,2)

. . C .
. . C .
. . . .

Note that the top-left corner means the topmost and leftmost coordinate of a block, which might be outside of the block. See block for an example.

To solve this puzzle, block should be placed in the following place:

. . B .
. B B .
. . . .

Output format
The first line is an integer , indicating the number of moves in an optimal solution.
In the following lines, you should output a sequence of moves indicating one possible optimal solution. Each line describes a move in the following format:

<block name> <from> <to>

which means to move the block whose top-left corner is to a place where its top-left corner is .

For example, with the example input above:

3 4
A A C .
A B C .
B B . .
B
0 1

One of the possible outputs is:

2
C (0,2) (1,3)
B (1,0) (0,1)

This means one optimal solution consists of 2 moves.
First we move block from to :

A A . .
A B . C
B B . C

And then we move block from to :

A A B .
A B B C
. . . C

Constraints

  • Block size won't exceed .
  • All inputs are guaranteed to be solvable within 201 steps, i.e. .

Notes

  • In the case where there are multiple solutions to the puzzle, you only need to print one of them.
  • Test cases will not be overly difficult, being a little wise about states and your program should have enough time to work out this challenge.
  • If you want to do a search, taking block shapes into account will save you some space.

Sample Input 

3 4
A A C .
A B C .
B B . .
B
0 1

Sample Output 

2
C (0,2) (1,3)
B (1,0) (0,1)

Tested by Patrick Spettel

primary_contest.tagline: A contest for functional programming enthusiasts

track.name: Functional Programming
track.descriptions: The art of programming with expressions and functions. Experience the challenge of programming without state. A good paradigm for those interested in Map-Reduce and parallel computing.

primary_contest.description:
The contest hosts 7 challenges ranging from algorithms to logics to compilers.

Problem Setters Joseph Abrahamson, Javran (Fang) Cheng, Ivan Buda Mandura, Stanislav Pak, Rajesh Kumar, Abhiranjan.

Validators Patrick Spettel, Stanislav Pak, Ray Williams Robinson Valiente, Ivan Buda Mandura, Bo You, Wanbo, Abhiranjan.

Languages allowed: Haskell, Racket, Clojure, OCaml, F#, Scala, Common Lisp and Erlang.

Want to contribute problems? Mail to hackers@hackerrank.com with the subject "Lambda Calculi".
primary_contest.name: Lambda Calculi - 9
